review.title: Pre-computed Liquid Spaces with Generative Neural Networks and Optical Flow
review.abstract: Liquids exhibit highly complex, non-linear behavior under changing simulation conditions such as user interactions. We propose a method to map this complex behavior over a parameter range onto a reduced representation based on space-time deformations. In order to represent the complexity of the full space of inputs, we use aligned deformations from optical flow solves, and we leverage the power of generative neural networks to synthesize additional deformations for refinement. We introduce a novel deformation-aware loss function, which enables optimization in the highly non-linear space of multiple deformations. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, we showcase the method with several complex examples in two and four dimensions. Our representation makes it possible to generate implicit surfaces of liquids very efficiently, which allows us to very efficiently display the scene from any angle, and to add secondary effects such as particle systems. We have implemented a mobile application with our full pipeline to demonstrate that real-time interaction is possible with our approach.

metadata.title: Pre-computed Liquid Spaces with Generative Neural Networks and Optical Flow

sections.text: Liquids exhibit highly complex, nonlinear behavior under changing simulation conditions such as user interactions. We propose a method to map this complex behavior over a parameter range to a reduced representation based on space-time deformations. To represent the complexity of the entire input space, we use aligned deformations from optical flow solutions and use the power of generative neural networks to synthesize additional deformations for refinement. We introduce a novel deformation-conscious loss function that allows optimization in the highly nonlinear space of multiple deformations. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, we present the method with several complex examples in two and four dimensions. Our representation allows us to generate implicit surfaces of liquids very efficiently, allowing us to depict the scene from any angle very efficiently and add secondary effects such as particle systems.

sections.heading: 3 Problem Description
sections.text: Considering a limit problem with a LPG interface, we consider the interface as a single space-time surface over time. We start with a series of these space-time surfaces, which we will define as such, although they are defined by a convex region of our simulation parameters. We assume that all parameter dimensions are standardized, i.e. that we are aware of the complex multiplicity of these surfaces as a whole that we want to capture and represent. We choose implicit functions that we represent as R3 × R + → R to represent specific instances of multiplicity, so that we consider these surfaces as a whole. sections.heading: 4.4 Evaluation
sections.text: To divide these samples into 2056 training samples, we will first explain a two-dimensional setup parameter space with two-dimensional surfaces. To this end, we will use the SDFs extracted from two-dimensional simulations of a drop falling into a pool. As a simulation parameter, we will select the size of the drop, and it will be its original X position. sections.heading: 5 Long-range Deformations
sections.text: Our neural network can successfully refine the deformations based on an initial series of pre-calculated deformations along the sides of the parameter space. Therefore, any improvement for these initial deformations is typically translated into improvements in the quality for the output of our neural network. Therefore, we will propose an additional step aimed at long-term correspondence before discussing more complex four-dimensional results. If we calculate the endpoint deformations, we have two closely related goals: the goal of precisely matching and establishing correct correspondences between source and target, the algorithm we use (optical flow), and many others such as the iterative methods of the closest point, working by matching the next distances. For inputs with significant differences, a deterioration of both desired qualities goes hand in hand: parts of the target shape can be lost, and the probability of reconstructing a target feature from an arbitrarily different source increases.

sections.heading: 6 Mobile Device Implementation
sections.text: To demonstrate the high performance that our representation achieves, we have implemented a proof-of-concept application for mobile devices. Our application is divided into two parts: a main loop that is used for surface creation and rendering, and a second loop that handles user interaction, and calculates a final deformation for the main loop that is to be displayed. Both loops work with separate threads and use double buffers to deliver the results. The high-performance tasks of our pipeline are calculated using RenderScript, which is a framework that distributes tasks across the CPU and GPU. Neural networks are instead calculated using separate threads and use double buffers to deliver the results. RenderScript computes the high-performance tasks of our pipeline, which distribute tasks across the CPU and GPU.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We have presented a novel method for predicting a complex fluid space with deformation-conscious neural networks. Based on the cho-sen representation, our approach enables real-time interactions with complex fluid effects. To our knowledge, we are also the first to introduce a machine learning approach that actively learns to deform surfaces. We believe it is exciting to see how such generative neural networks can be successfully applied to problems in the context of flow simulations. In the future, it will be interesting to simulate other types of phenomena with our synthesis pipeline, and we plan to investigate how our deformation-aware networks work for optical flow problems outside the realm of flow simulation.

metadata.abstractText: Liquids exhibit highly complex, non-linear behavior under changing simulation conditions such as user interactions. We propose a method to map this complex behavior over a parameter range onto a reduced representation based on space-time deformations. In order to represent the complexity of the full space of inputs, we use aligned deformations from optical flow solves, and we leverage the power of generative neural networks to synthesize additional deformations for refinement. We introduce a novel deformation-aware loss function, which enables optimization in the highly non-linear space of multiple deformations. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, we showcase the method with several complex examples in two and four dimensions. Our representation makes it possible to generate implicit surfaces of liquids very efficiently, which allows us to very efficiently display the scene from any angle, and to add secondary effects such as particle systems. We have implemented a mobile application with our full pipeline to demonstrate that real-time interaction is possible with our approach.
